Situation1: The partner seems mildly stressed after a routine workday.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story: I walk through the door, phone still in hand, my mind buzzing with the day’s calls. My girlfriend sits on the couch, her shoulders tense, eyes fixed on the TV but not really watching. I know that look—she’s had a rough day. I want to sit beside her, listen, and offer comfort, like a good boyfriend should. But my phone vibrates again: another prospect, another chance to hit my quota. I remember the last call, the customer’s barrage of technical questions that left me fumbling, the script useless in my hands. My manager expects me to handle every objection, to sound confident and knowledgeable, even when I’m not. I glance at my girlfriend, then at my phone. She needs me to be present, to care. My job needs me to be sharp, responsive, and available. My heart aches with the pull in both directions, the fear of letting someone down no matter what I choose.
